solution_line_template: The items he returned were valued at ${returned_tv_cost} + ${returned_bike_cost} = $<<{returned_tv_cost}+{returned_bike_cost}={total_returned_value}>>{total_returned_value}

So far he is out {initial_amazon_spend}-{total_returned_value} = <<{initial_amazon_spend}-{total_returned_value}={current_out_of_pocket}>>{current_out_of_pocket} after recouping {total_returned_value}.
An item that is 20% more expensive cost {base_multiplier} + {percentage_increase_decimal} = {increase_factor} times as much as the item
So that means the bike he sold cost ${returned_bike_cost} * {increase_factor} = $<<{returned_bike_cost}*{increase_factor}={sold_bike_original_cost}>>{sold_bike_original_cost}

From the bike that he had bought for {sold_bike_original_cost}, he was out {sold_bike_original_cost}-{sold_bike_sale_price} =<<{sold_bike_original_cost}-{sold_bike_sale_price}={bike_loss}>>{bike_loss}

If he also bought a toaster worth {toaster_cost}, he was out {out_of_pocket_after_bike_sale}+{toaster_cost} = <<{out_of_pocket_after_bike_sale}+{toaster_cost}={final_out_of_pocket}>>{final_out_of_pocket}
